NIELSEN, Secretary, U.S. Department of Homeland Security, Robert COWAN, Director, National Benefits Center, UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY, and UNITED STATES CITIZENSHIP AND IMMIGRATION SERVICES
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Defendant: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services, Department of Homeland Security (government agencies)

evidence.text: challenge the federal government’s policy of refusing to adjudicate their SIJS petitions in accordance with the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA). The government’s blanket denial... violates the controlling statute and regulations. In addition, the government has a practice of delaying the adjudication... in violation of a clear statutory requirement... These statutory violations... violate the law
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Administrative Procedure Act (APA)

evidence.text: See 8 U.S.C. § 1101(a)(27)(J)(i)-(ii). In each Plaintiff’s case, a Washington state court has made these requisite findings
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

evidence.text: Plaintiffs thus seek declaratory and injunctive relief to enjoin this unlawful implementation

Docket entries show no related case numbers (all entries reference Case No. 2:19-cv-321 only)

Plaintiffs bring this action on behalf of themselves and all others who are similarly situated pursuant to Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 23(a) and 23(b)(2). A class action is proper because this action involves questions of law and fact common to the classes, the classes are so numerous that joinder of all members is impractical, Plaintiffs’ claims are typical of the claims of the classes, Plaintiffs will fairly and adequately protect the interests of the respective classes, and Defendants have acted on grounds that apply generally to the class, so that final injunctive relief or corresponding declaratory relief is appropriate with respect to the class as a whole.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

evidence.text: Plaintiffs seek to represent the following statewide class: All individuals who have been issued predicate SIJS orders by Washington state courts after turning eighteen years old but prior to turning twenty-one years old, and have submitted or will submit SIJS petitions to USCIS prior to turning twenty-one years old.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

evidence.text: Defendants have a policy of requiring that the predicate SIJS order be issued by a state court with the authority to make a legal conclusion about returning the youth to his parent’s custody. Pursuant to this policy, Defendants have denied or will deny all SIJS petitions filed by youth who have obtained SIJS orders in Washington state courts after turning 18 years old but prior to turning 21.
evidence.source_document: Complaint - Class Action for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiffs allege USCIS denied SIJS petitions to youth aged 18-20 based on a new policy requiring state courts to have authority to reunify with parents, despite the SIJS statute not requiring this, with examples of individual plaintiffs' cases involving abuse, neglect, and state court SIJS orders.
